Authors: Olschewski, R; Bebi, P; Teich, M; Hayek, UW; Grêt-Regamey, A
Author Full Names: Olschewski, Roland; Bebi, Peter; Teich, Michaela; Hayek, Ulrike Wissen; Gret-Regamey, Adrienne
Article Title: Avalanche protection by forests - A choice experiment in the Swiss Alps
Author Keywords: Cost-benefit analysis; Environmental services; Public goods; Natural hazards; Risk; Visualization
Abstract: Forests provide a variety of ecosystem goods and services to society, which often have the typical characteristics of a public good: non-excludability and non-rivalry. One of these services is avalanche protection of forests. A monetary valuation of this service would be helpful to provide efficient and effective protection to the local population. We present the results of a case study from the Swiss Alps, where we determined the willingness to pay for avalanche protection based on a choice experiment combined with virtual reality visualizations. Furthermore, we compare these results with the costs of alternative technical measures for natural hazard mitigation as well as with the results of a risk-based evaluation. We conclude that the willingness to pay for avalanche protection of forests is about the same range as the collective risk related to a 300-years avalanche event and within a range similar to the per-household costs of alternative measures. However, willingness to pay is substantially higher than the costs of silvicultural measures to maintain protection forest. (C) 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Aaijaz, N; Salleh, SSBM; Ibrahim, MDB
Author Full Names: Aaijaz, Naila; Salleh, Siti Sarwani Bt Mohamed; Ibrahim, Mohamed Dahlan B.
Article Title: Cooperative Social Responsibility: The Gap Model Approach and Empirical Derivation to Members' Satisfaction
Source Title: INNOVATION AND SUSTAINABLE COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE: FROM REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT TO WORLD ECONOMIES, VOLS 1-5
Conference Title: 18th International-Business-Information-Management-Association Conference
Author Keywords: Corporate/ cooperative social responsibility; customer loyalty; Kelantan; Malaysia; Satisfaction
Abstract: Purpose - This research is to identify the Koop Guru's members' satisfaction magnitude over its CSR schemes. If this research comes out with a positive result, this may signify the most influential impact of Koop Guru's CSR activities or scheme in Kota Bharu Kelantan Malaysia towards its member's welfare. Design/methodology/ approach - This study is quantitative in nature using the responses of 30 cooperative customers/ members who answered a survey questionnaire on a face to face basis. Findings - The results of the study demonstrate how corporate social responsibility (CSR) schemes influence customer satisfaction and also examine CSR's impact on membership growth and brand loyalty. The study's hypothesized relationships were principally supported, i.e. company's offerings and customers/ members expectations are positively associated with members' satisfaction mediated by membership growth and loyalty. CSR schemes play an important role in customer/ members satisfaction, which in turn, influences trust and brand effect. Research limitations/ implications - While the results are clear and have strong salience to the cooperative industry in Malaysia, applications of the findings beyond Malaysia should take into account other factors such as the nature of co-operative industry, the perception, behavior and demographics of co-operative customers as well as the strategic focus of co-operative toward CSR. Practical implications - This study provides a set of findings relating to CSR schemes initiatives and perception of customers/ members satisfaction towards building loyalty and satisfaction. Originality value - This paper exhibits an empirical derivation of CSR schemes initiatives measured from customers/ members' point of view, and is expected to be a benchmark for other cooperatives in Malaysia to learn about cooperative strategy development and customers/ members' retention.

Article Title: A Cross-Cultural Analysis of Ethically Conscious Consumer Behaviors
Source Title: INNOVATION AND SUSTAINABLE COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE: FROM REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT TO WORLD ECONOMIES, VOLS 1-5
Conference Title: 18th International-Business-Information-Management-Association Conference
Author Keywords: Ethically Conscious Behavior; Ethical consumption; Ethical Decision Making; Identity Theory; Issue-Contingent Ethical Decision Making; Theory of Planned Behavior
Keywords Plus: SUSTAINABLE FOOD-CONSUMPTION; DECISION-MAKING; PLANNED BEHAVIOR; PURCHASE INTENTIONS; MORAL IDENTITY; ORGANIC FOODS; FAIR TRADE; ATTITUDE; FRAMEWORK; DONT
Abstract: Although consumer consciousness concerning sustainability has increased over the years, behavioral patterns are not unequivocally consistent with attitudes. Consumer research to understand the adoption of ethically conscious behaviors and ethically desirable products is therefore important. This paper adopts a cross-country approach and analyses the consumers' ethical decision making process. A model of individual ethical decision making is presented and tested empirically by structural equation modeling. The study highlights that environmentally conscious consumers are more likely to engage in environmental friendly actions. Hence the demand of environment friendly products may be enhanced by appealing on environmental beliefs of the consumers or by focusing on the product features linking to environmental beliefs or both.

Authors: Benería, L; Deere, CD; Kabeer, N
Author Full Names: Beneria, Lourdes; Deere, Carmen Diana; Kabeer, Naila
Article Title: GENDER AND INTERNATIONAL MIGRATION: GLOBALIZATION, DEVELOPMENT, AND GOVERNANCE
Author Keywords: Gender; international migration; globalization; development; governance
Keywords Plus: SOCIAL REPRODUCTION; LATIN-AMERICA; CARE; CRISIS; REMITTANCES; MIGRANTS; ECONOMY; POLICY; WOMEN
Abstract: This contribution examines the connections between gender and international migration around three themes: globalization, national economic development, and governance. First, it discusses the connections between globalization and the multiplicity of processes that have contributed to international migration and its feminization, arguing that gender awareness is crucial to understanding these processes. Gender analysis makes visible the increasing commodification of care work on a global scale and highlights how the organization of families is changing. Second, it analyzes the various avenues through which migration may contribute to or hinder economic development, highlighting why remittances, in particular by women, have featured very positively in the migration and development policy discourse. Third, it discusses how issues of citizenship affect the migrant population, showing how gender analysis highlights many challenges with regard to nation-based notions of citizenship, particularly in the receiving countries.

Authors: Chen, Y; Xu, RY; Yang, JX
Author Full Names: Chen, Yan; Xu, Ruiyang; Yang, Jiaxing
Article Title: An Exploration on OFDI Determinants of Developing Countries-Based on the Comparative Analysis with Developed Countries
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: developing countries; OFDI; determinants; comparative analysis
Abstract: From the perspective of OFDI theory of developing countries, this thesis expands the category of OFDI economic determinants using investment development path (IDP) theory as its starting point. This thesis incorporates economic development level, OFDI, export level into its research framework and on this basis have institutional determinants added to analyze the roles that institutional environment and policy support play in OFDI of developing countries. This thesis adopts the panel data of 36 countries from 1984 to 2008 and divides the study sample by economic development level. By studying the roles that those different determinants play in various development phases of OFDI, this thesis reveals the variation rules of OFDI impact caused by different determinants. The results show that: economic determinants have a growing significant influence on the different development phases of OFDI; institutional environment has both a positive and negative significant influence on OFDI of developing countries. Some factors also have a significant influence on OFDI of developed countries, but they are all negative influence. Policy support has a positive influence on all the countries, but with different significance.

Article Title: Structural Change in Fruit and Vegetable Production in Germany
Source Title: XXVIII INTERNATIONAL HORTICULTURAL CONGRESS ON SCIENCE AND HORTICULTURE FOR PEOPLE (IHC2010): INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM ON INTEGRATING CONSUMERS AND ECONOMIC SYSTEMS
Conference Title: 28th International Horticultural Congress on Science and Horticulture for People (IHC) / International Symposium on Integrating Consumers and Economic Systems
Author Keywords: structural change; horticulture; Germany
Abstract: The two most recent horticultural censuses from 1994 and 2005 provide a descriptive analysis of the structural change in the horticultural production sector in Germany. Data on the number of farms, the production area and the labour input are available. Some 34,702 farms were engaged in horticultural production which utilized some 209,703 ha and employed 122,184 full time equivalents. Two thirds of these farms were specialized in horticultural production activities which used 78% of the production area. The fruit and vegetable sectors each have a significant influence on the development of the production structure in Germany. Of the total production area used by specialized farms, 29% are dedicated to fruit and 42% to vegetable production. However, the number of farms producing vegetables decreased by 42% between 1994 and 2005. On the other hand, the production area increased by more than one third to 97,218 ha. The development of specialized fruit producers was similar. In the same period, the number of farms producing fruit and specialized fruit producers decreased by about one third each to 16,594 farms and 7,345 farms respectively. A slight reduction in the production area for specialized fruit producing farms to 46,308 ha was observed, whereas the fruit production area increased by 12% to 82,144 ha. The result of these developments are larger but fewer farms. Comparing the labour input and production area reveals improvements in labour productivity in specialized fruit and vegetable production. Furthermore, horticultural production has become more professional today, due to the concentration of production activities in greater and more specialized farms. It is likely that these developments will continue in the future.

Article Title: HEALTH CARE ECONOMY IN STRUCTURE OF THE MODERN MARKET RELATIONS
Source Title: VITH RYSKULOV READINGS: SOCIO-ECONOMIC MODERNIZATION OF KAZAKHSTAN UNDER CONDITIONS OF GLOBAL FINANCIAL INSTABILITY
Conference Title: International Scientific Forum of the 6th Ryskulov's Readings - Socio-Economic Modernization of Kazakhstan Under Conditions of Global Financial Instability
Author Keywords: healthcare economics; Medical treatment processes; competitiveness; competition in the health system
Abstract: Purpose - to explain and analyze how to achieve maximum effect in providing medical care for a given cost. The objectives of health economics include: determination of the costs of different types of care determination and the determination of material, labor and financial reserves, subject to management, identifying ways to improve the health economic assessment of health plans. Methodology - to achieve our purpose we use theoretical, analytical andstatistical analysis. Originality/value - Health economics is a part of medical and economic science, which arose at the intersection of sociology, social medicine and public health organization, political economy and the particular economy. It examines the manifestations and the use of objective economic laws and relations in health care as one of the sectors of the economy, all kinds of efficiency of health (social, medical and economic), identifies and develops methods for the rational use of material and financial resources, identifies reserves all of its health areas. Finding - As we know search and study of specific criteria of competitiveness within the medical facility (medical practice), this way, which in our opinion, currently the most accessible and it is productive in terms of the development and implementation of management decisions on the organization of advanced (jet), production of medical services. In the future, with the formation of real competition in the markets of medical services, such medical institutions (medical practice) will initially have a high degree of competitiveness.

Book Editors: Skarpa, P; Ryant, P; Cerkal, R; Polak, O; Kovarnik, J; Vyskocil, I
Article Title: THE INFLUENCE OF WIND TURBINES ON THE MORTALITY OF BIRDS - PRELIMINARY RESULTS
Conference Title: MendelNet International Ph.D. Students Conference
Author Keywords: wind; wind energy; wind turbines; landscape; birds
Abstract: Evaluation of the impact of wind turbines on the avifauna, are among the most important documents in the evaluation of the impact of wind power installation on the environment and is an essential part. The influence can be divided into three groups: 1) interference (alone or the presence of noise), 2) mortality due to collision with a building, 3) loss, removal or disturbance and habitat. The aim of my work is to evaluate the impact of wind turbines on the birds mortality of alone, without examining other impacts. The methodology is readmitted from Kocvara and Polasek (2005) and consists in determining the three selected monitoring sites throughout the year with a repeat at least twice a month during the period from March to November and once a month during the period from December to February. If a check can not take place as scheduled, executed as soon as possible. During the period from January 2012 to September 2012 were by this method monitored wind farms in Horni Lodenice (9 wind turbines), Ostruzna (6 wind turbines), and Hranicne Petrovice (2 wind turbines), and were found only two dead individuals - White Wagtail and Great Tit. Provisional results indicate no significant the influence of wind turbines on the birds mortality of. While watching, however, met with the question of predation in the wild. To what extent can predators represent distortion of the research. On this aspect in the future focus and we will follow.

Article Title: Study on the Impact of Economic Factors on Insolvencies at a Global, European Level and at the Level of Romania
Source Title: INNOVATION AND SUSTAINABLE COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE: FROM REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT TO WORLD ECONOMIES, VOLS 1-5
Conference Title: 18th International-Business-Information-Management-Association Conference
Author Keywords: insolvencies; economic growth; the stock market index; the opening degree of economy; the reference interest of the central bank; inflation
Abstract: Our study has as a goal the analysis of the way in which economic factors influence the number of insolvencies, at a global and european level and especially at the level of Romania. The analysis performed for the period of 2005-2011 has underlined that the evolution of insolvencies is influenced by the following macroeconomic factors: economic growth, the stock market index, the opening degree of economy, the reference interest of the central bank and inflation. In order to test if the macroeconomic factors influence the number of insolvencies, we used the multiple regression, with the help of the statistical software SPSS 19.

Article Title: The Labor Market Impact of Immigration: A Quasi-Experiment Exploiting Immigrant Location Rules in Germany
Keywords Plus: YOUNG NATIVE WORKERS; NATURAL EXPERIMENT; ETHNIC ENCLAVES; WAGES; EMPLOYMENT; MIGRATION; OUTFLOWS; INFLOWS
Abstract: With the fall of the Berlin Wall, ethnic Germans living in eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union were given the opportunity to migrate to Germany. Within 15 years, 2.8 million individuals had done so. Upon arrival, these immigrants were exogenously allocated to different regions to ensure an even distribution across the country. Their inflow can therefore be seen as a quasi-experiment of immigration. I analyze the effect of these inflows on skill-specific employment rates and wages. The results indicate a displacement effect of 3.1 unemployed workers for every 10 immigrants that find a job, but no effect on relative wages.

Article Title: Application of Enterprise Architecture Supported by Organization Complexity and Resource-based View
Source Title: INNOVATION AND SUSTAINABLE COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE: FROM REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT TO WORLD ECONOMIES, VOLS 1-5
Conference Title: 18th International-Business-Information-Management-Association Conference
Author Keywords: enterprise architecture; organizational complexity; strategic resources; architectural vision
Abstract: Organizations have to react to the accelerating changes and complexity of their environment to survive in future. They call for higher flexibility and operational efficiency that is in fact the key contribution of enterprise architecture according to its definition. Enterprise architecture provides supportive instruments to manage an organizational change on both business and information technology sides. Unfortunately, many enterprise architecture activities do not contribute to an organization performance, frequently by reason of insufficient understanding of the organization needs or complexity. This paper proposes an extension of standard enterprise architecture practices through the utilization of organizational complexity and strategic resources theories, which can better explain the organization's situation and focus the enterprise architecture accordingly.

Article Title: Survival Environment of Changzhou Medium and Small-sized Enterprises under Background of China's Economic Transformation
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF CHINA PRIVATE ECONOMY INNOVATION INTERNATIONAL FORUM 2012
Conference Title: China Private Economy Innovation International Forum
Conference Sponsor: Yangtze River Delta Private Econ Res Assoc, Taizhou Branch,Journal Econ & Social Syst Comparison,Taizhou Merchant Assoc,Taizhou Univ,Ningbo Univ, Sch Business
Author Keywords: China's economic transformation; medium- and small-sized enterprises; survival environment
Abstract: Changzhou City lies in the Yangtze River Region, and it is one of the areas with the most rapid economic development. In the process of Changzhou economic development, medium and small-sized enterprises have played very important roles which include adding economic aggregates, accumulating social wealth, optimizing resources'. allocation, innovating technology, adding working chances and stabilizing social order. Because China's current economy is facing upgrading and transformation, the national, international economic environments are very complicated, and the adverse effect of the world financial crisis and European debt crisis still exist, so the survival environment of medium and small-sized enterprises in Changzhou City have started to deteriorate. Many enterprises are facing a survival crisis and development test. How to help these enterprises acquire new development power by depending on technology innovation and the transformation of economic gains are the inventible questions needed to be considered by macroscopic and microcosmic decision makers. Some measures about Changzhou medium and small-sized enterprises' survival environment and their optimization are mentioned in this paper, and they are all under the background of China's economic transformation.

Authors: Karno, MR; Noordin, SA; Abd Rahman, S; Talib, A
Author Full Names: Karno, Md. Razib; Noordin, Siti Arfah; Abd Rahman, Safawi; Talib, Anuar
Article Title: Facilitating Resource Allocation Decision through Data Mining: The Case of UTM Library
Source Title: INNOVATION AND SUSTAINABLE COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE: FROM REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT TO WORLD ECONOMIES, VOLS 1-5
Conference Title: 18th International-Business-Information-Management-Association Conference
Author Keywords: Bibliomining; Evidence Based Research; Bibliometrics; Data Mining
Abstract: Library has vastly developed from conventional services to digital services in these recent years. The demand from the users, institutions, international organization needs and technology advancement has change the library either in their budget cost or in their decision making approach. The library organization nowadays undeniably relies on bibliographic data and digital sources outcome to plan for activities and future development, however few have used this as an advantage. We chose the Library of Universiti Telcnologi Malaysia for the case study as it has nearly 1 million records of collection in various formats. The huge library bibliographic data could be statistically patterned and clustered for indicating relationship among them. Bibliomining term that are similar to library data mining fields are tools that can visualize how libraries manage their cost, staff activity, customer service, user needs, marketing, popular books, circulation, reference transaction, quality of collection, educational programs etc. The purpose of this paper is to propose the implementation of bibliomining to the library data warehousing as a tool to assist library management in making decision. The data set consists of patrons' data and loan registration records between 2005 and 2010. The loan registration record contains each patron's ID number, time and detailed information regarding book loaned and their call numbers. The loan registration record has a huge data set and therefore, efficient technique must be applied in the process of analyzing and pre-processing. An interview with UTM Deputy Chief Librarian will be conducted to validate all the findings.

Book Editors: Skarpa, P; Ryant, P; Cerkal, R; Polak, O; Kovarnik, J; Vyskocil, I
Article Title: OPTIMALIZATION OF METHODS SUITABLE FOR ASSESSMENT OF VOLATILES IN BEER
Conference Title: MendelNet International Ph.D. Students Conference
Author Keywords: beer; volatiles; solid phase microextraction; gas chromatography
Abstract: The name of this thesis Optimalization of methods suitable for assessment of volatiles in beer expresses the methods and the aims of research. In great detail it determines the optimal method of chromatographic analysis and the most suitable way of preparing sample for analysis by gas chromotography. For assessment of the most suitable stacionary phase of gas chromotography was tested column DB WAX and DB5. Next was to determined the most suitable temperature program for effective separation of analysed substance. Detection of analyses was made on flame ionizated detector and mass spectrometer. For separation volatiles from matrix and for their preconcentration was tested liquid extraction and headspace solid phase microextraction (SPME), which was also compared with analysis of gaseous phase without using extraction. SPME, which was showed as the most useful, had more attention. Volatiles were izolated with different combination of sorbents, sorption was at various temperatures, they were also examined with the addition of salt in the sample and using ultrasonic bath.

Article Title: Study on the Effective Way of Motivation of Knowledge Workers
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: knowledge workers; knowledge worker motivation; knowledge worker management
Abstract: Knowledge Workers are important components of core competitiveness of a company. Corporate knowledge creation, resource utilization and allocation, profit maximization and a series of goals depends on a knowledge-based talent. Because of the special nature of knowledge workers, the motivation of knowledge workers requires more than money, and their own growth and achievements are more important. Therefore, how to effectively motivate them is a big problem that managers need to consider. Based on the analysis of the characteristic of knowledge workers, this paper argues that spirit-based incentive is more important for knowledge workers, whereby some effective methods of motivating knowledge workers are promoted.

Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)

Abstract: Sustainable development is a long-term economic growth mode, which can satisfy the needs of the present without compromising future generations ability to meet their needs, it is one of the basic requirements of scientific development concept. Sustainable development includes social, environmental and economic sustainable development. Economic development, social development and environmental protection are interdependent sustainable development mutually reinforcing components. The best model for sustainable economic development is material, human, ecological three kinds of capital common proliferation. Article Title: Reference and Consideration on Auditing Reform in China Brought by Sarbanes - Oxley Act (SOX)
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: Sarbanes-Oxley Act (SOX); auditing reform; supervision of the CPA profession; internal control
Abstract: Sarbanes-Oxley Act (Sarbanes-Oxley Act), also known as 2002 Public Company Accounting Reform and Investor Protection Act (herein after referred to as SOX), was released on July 30, 2002. From July 15, 2006 onwards, all companies listed in the U. S. (including all Chinese companies listed in the U. S.) will be required to comply strictly with bill enacted by the United States. Different from the previous bill, the bill have raised stringent requirements on the company's internal control, capital market regulation, supervision of the CPA profession and other aspects, and have set the accountability mechanism and the corresponding penalties. Its implementation has caused strong repercussions not only in the world, but also in the national capital market regulation. Many countries have begun to draw on the spirit of SOX, to strengthen market supervision. This paper have tried to throw light on the main content of SOX especially on the CPA industry and internal control monitoring, it also have analyzed the background and significance of SOX. Combined with explaining the current status of auditing reform, it has discussed its impact and enlightenment in Chinese auditing reform.

Article Title: Enforcing the Cash Dividends of the Listed Companies to Recycle the Equity Culture
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: listed company; dividends; equity culture
Abstract: Compared with the mature markets, dividends of the listed company in China pay more attention on stock dividends than cash dividends, making a unique equity culture. To reshape China's equity culture, it is an important foundation to implement forcing cash dividends. The legislative measures include: determine reasonably the proportion of cash dividends; introduce the complaint to force to distribute dividends; strengthen the penalties for the violation of the cash dividends. The main measures in recycling the equity culture in China include: emphasis on performance growth and cash dividends; performance growth and cash dividends maintain a positive correlation with stock price; carry out the education on the company value and the investor's investing value.

Article Title: Accounting Standards Transformation, Earnings Management and Auditors' Forensic Capabilities
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: New Accounting Standards; Earnings Management; Auditing Opinion
Abstract: We studied the auditors' capabilities of perceiving the earnings management of listed companies in Shenzhen and Shanghai Securities Markets by selecting data three years before and after the implementation of New Accounting Standards. After controlling the impact of the existing identifiable factors having nothing to do with accounting standards transformation, it has been found that the auditors' capabilities of perceiving corporate earnings management significantly increased after the implementation of New Accounting Standards, the probability of issuing non-standard audit opinion on the audited companies which have conducted earnings management is greater than that before the implementation, but the audit opinion is less severe, most of the non-standard audit opinions are unqualified opinion with emphasis notes. By the way, the issuing of auditors' reports has a certain difference among industries, the industries greatly influenced by New Accounting Standards and obtained a high degree of social concern get higher proportion of non-standard audit opinion, but the difference was not significant. It is worth mentioning that the situation of finance and insurance industry which has a high degree of social concern appears abnormal, the proportion of non-standard audit opinion is higher than any other industries before the implementation of the New Accounting Standards, however after the implementation, all sample companies have obtained standard audit opinion under the situation of earning management is pervasive in finance and insurance industry.

Article Title: STRENGTHENING OF THE CONTRACTUAL BASIS AS A TREND OF DEVELOPING OF LABOR LAW
Source Title: VITH RYSKULOV READINGS: SOCIO-ECONOMIC MODERNIZATION OF KAZAKHSTAN UNDER CONDITIONS OF GLOBAL FINANCIAL INSTABILITY
Conference Title: International Scientific Forum of the 6th Ryskulov's Readings - Socio-Economic Modernization of Kazakhstan Under Conditions of Global Financial Instability
Author Keywords: labor law; collective agreements; employment contracts; agreements; social and labor relations
Abstract: Purpose - the aim of the research work is to examine the contractual method of regulation of labor and relations directly connected to it in the aspect of identifying the correlation of constitutional law and contractual regulation. Methodology - the methodological basis of the research is the general scientific method of studying the theory, labor laws and practices of individual contractual regulation of labor relations and particular scientific methods of knowledge such as formally-legal, comparatively-legal, logical, historically-legal, systematical. Originality/value - the significance of the research is that it examines the method of the labor law of the Republic of Kazakhstan, which discloses its peculiarity consisting in the contractual regulation of labor and directly connected to it relations. Findings - this article attempts to clarify the characteristic trends of the development of labor relations in the Republic of Kazakhstan with the adoption of the Labor Code of the Republic of Kazakhstan (hereinafter - LC RK) on May 15th, 2007. Analysis of the Labor Code of the Republic of Kazakhstan suggests that individual-contract method is the primary method for the regulation of labor and directly connected to it relations. With the transition to a market economy, the range of possibilities of centralized regulation of social and labor relations becomes narrow and mandatory (imperative) rules of labor law lose their widespread nature. The combination of private and public basis had great influence on the limits of the rights of the employee and the employer in establishing conditions of employment and collective agreements. Hence the limits of the rights of the employee and the employer in establishing conditions of employment and collective agreements are limited to prohibition of worsening the position of the employee, compared to the normative acts (in favorem). Contractual way to establish the rights and responsibilities of subjects in the labor law is modified. Due to the nature of the method of regulation labor law can not be attributed either to a private or a public law.

Article Title: Internal Control and the Impact on Corporate Governance, in Romanian Listed Companies
Source Title: INNOVATION AND SUSTAINABLE COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE: FROM REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT TO WORLD ECONOMIES, VOLS 1-5
Conference Title: 18th International-Business-Information-Management-Association Conference
Author Keywords: internal control; corporate governance; audit; control risk
Abstract: In Europe and around the world, after the financial crisis, some measures have been taken in order to stabilize the financial system. Through present research we analyze the statements regarding the internal control in corporate governance, statements made by both external auditors and those responsible with the management of listed entities. These statements help the auditor in preparing the audit plan. Following this review, the auditor determines necessary staff and time needed for the audit.. We analyzed effectiveness of internal control in companies listed on Bucharest Stock Exchange. An effective internal control leads to a fair presentation of the financial statements and thus increases stakeholders' confidence in the financial statements. Control risk is a risk that the auditor can't eliminate it, but may decrease it.

Authors: Mironiuc, M; Robu, IB; Carp, M
Author Full Names: Mironiuc, Marilena; Robu, Ioan-Bogdan; Carp, Mihai
Article Title: The Use of Survival Analysis for Obtaining Audit Evidence in Assessing Companies' Ability to Continue as a Going Concern
Source Title: INNOVATION AND SUSTAINABLE COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE: FROM REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT TO WORLD ECONOMIES, VOLS 1-5
Conference Title: 18th International-Business-Information-Management-Association Conference
Author Keywords: survival analysis; duration models; audit evidence; going concern; insolvency
Abstract: In the context of the current economic crisis, the fundamental role of the auditor is to guarantee the accuracy of the financial statements reported by the companies quoted on financial markets. According to international standards on auditing, within their mission, the auditors must also evaluate the company's ability to continue its activity within a determined time horizon, without becoming insolvent, thus ensuring that the quality criteria concerning financial reporting are preserved. On its objective, independent, and professional opinion depend the strategic decisions of all the stakeholders, and the auditor carries all the responsibility for planning the mission, collecting the evidence, and performing the necessary procedures for issuing the final report. Within the mission, the auditors must support their audit opinion on sufficient and appropriate audit evidence, and the analytical procedures ensure a series of comparative information at the level of analyzed periods or branch. This study aims to support a model based on quantitative analysis techniques to evaluate the ability of the audited company to continue its activity, without being subject to the risk of insolvency, based on duration models using survival analysis. Obtaining the mortality tables, as well as estimating the probability and time of survival after the risk of insolvency are useful to the auditor in the evaluation of the audited company's compliance with drawing the annual financial statements based on the going concern assumption. The study was performed on a sample of 77 companies quoted in the Bucharest Stock Exchange, subject to the risk of insolvency in the period 2008-2011. The data were treated and the results were obtained using the SPSS 19.0 and SAS EG 4.2 statistical software.

Article Title: Knowledge Management and Management Accounting Decisions-Experimental Study
Source Title: INNOVATION AND SUSTAINABLE COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE: FROM REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT TO WORLD ECONOMIES, VOLS 1-5
Conference Title: 18th International-Business-Information-Management-Association Conference
Author Keywords: knowledge management; accounting; experiment; UAE
Abstract: This research targets to examine how participants from organizations in UAE acquire, share and utilize knowledge. The study replicates the study of Edward et.al (2006) of CIMA project about how knowledge is managed within management accounting decisions. An experiment is run and 26 participants from different industries (municipality, hotel, insurance, retail, education, travel and food). Participants were given case studies, one represents a routine accounting decision in planning and a strategic decision. The intention was to explore what is knowledge relate to each decision, how acquired, processed and used. The findings show that participants do not differentiate between information and knowledge and all organizations have effective methods of acquiring knowledge in databases, files and other documents and different information are kept and used for the different decisions. Knowledge for routine decisions are processed via computerized programs but participants could not explain how they process knowledge in their minds and how they utilize in the different situations. The study revealed that there are differences in knowledge and its management according to industry, managerial level and type of decision and there were reflections of the UAE's business environment with its mutli-culture and having specific strategies that encourage tourism industry and tightly regulate insurance.

Authors: Nepal, P; Grala, RK; Grebner, DL
Author Full Names: Nepal, Prakash; Grala, Robert K.; Grebner, Donald L.
Article Title: Financial feasibility of increasing carbon sequestration in harvested wood products in Mississippi
Author Keywords: Carbon; Compensation; Financial feasibility; Net Present Value; Rotation age; Wood products
Keywords Plus: FOREST CARBON; PINE PLANTATIONS; SINKS; MODEL; COST
Abstract: Longer forest rotation ages can potentially increase accumulation of carbon in harvested wood products due to a larger proportion of sawlogs that can be used for manufacturing durable wood products such as lumber and plywood. This study quantified amounts of carbon accumulated in wood products harvested from loblolly pine (Pious taeda L) stands grown in Mississippi by extending rotation ages traditionally used to manage these stands for timber. The financial viability of this approach was examined based on carbon payments received by landowners for sequestering carbon in standing trees and harvested wood products. Results indicated a potential to increase carbon accumulated in wood products by 16.11 metric tons (t) of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO(2)e) per hectare (ha) for a rotation increase of 5 years and 67.07 tCO(2)e/ha for a rotation increase of 65 years. Carbon prices of $50/tCO(2)e and $110/tCO(2)e would be required to provide a sufficient incentive to forest landowners to extend rotations by 5 and 10 years, respectively. With 2.8 million ha of loblolly pine stands in Mississippi, this translates to a possible increase in wood products carbon of 45 million tCO(2)e and 80 million tCO(2)e for harvest ages increased by 5 and 10 years, respectively. Higher carbon prices lengthened rotation ages modestly due to low present values of carbon accumulated with long rotations. (C) 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Article Title: COMPARISON OF NON-DIRECT METHODS FOR ESTIMATION OF NITROGEN STATUS AND CANOPY STRUCTURE IN SPRING BARLEY
Conference Title: MendelNet International Ph.D. Students Conference
Author Keywords: spectral reflectance; vegetation indices; nitrogen; flavonols; UV radiation; PAR radiation
Abstract: The main objective of this study was to compare numerous vegetation indices derived from reflectance measurements in range 350 - 2500 nm (using the instrument FieldSpec 3 equipped with fiber optics) with in-vivo measured flavonols and chlorophyll content and derived Nitrogen Balance Index (NBI) (using the instrument Dualex). The sensitivity of individual parameters to genotypic variability and canopy structure was tested in two spring barley varieties ('Barke' and 'Bonus') and three sowing densities (1, 3 and 5 million germinable seeds). Furthermore, the effect of UV and PAR radiation on flavonols content was studied within independent experiment to ensure robustness of the selected parameters for the diagnosis of nutritional status and structure of vegetation. The results show that content of flavonols provides more uniform outcome with less influence of sowing density, but with a certain effect of leaf age. In addition, within the variety 'Bonus' significant effect of lowest sowing density was found. It is also evident that at higher doses of nitrogen the effect on flavonol content is saturating.

Article Title: WHO CARES? GENDER, REPRODUCTION, AND CARE CHAINS OF BURMESE MIGRANT WORKERS IN THAILAND
Author Keywords: Citizenship; reproductive labor; Burmese migrant workers; Thailand
Abstract: This study analyzes the challenges facing Burmese women factory workers in Thailand who seek to secure the daily reproduction of their labor power as well as the generational reproduction of their children. It illustrates how the reproduction of workers' labor is crucial for the social reproduction of a global economy in which migration is increasingly central to the changing contours of economic development and accumulation. Based on twenty-four months of research, which included life history interviews and survey responses obtained at three sites of factory production in Thailand, the study charts the complexities of Burmese migrant workers' transborder care strategies, as they manage their responsibilities to their children and natal families. Moreover, in analyzing the care burdens of migrant women employed in non-care sectors, this contribution expands the global care chain framework and adds to the understanding of the intersection of productive and reproductive work in contemporary globalization

Article Title: Application of Improved-PROMETHEE Methods for Decision Making in Investing
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: value investing; improved-PROMETHEE; entropy; weight
Abstract: This paper introduces the improved-PROMETHEE methods to the decision making process of value investing. Five performance criteria are used for measuring the growth potential of firms and are represented by weighted moving average numbers based on the real financial data. And the weights of the five criteria are obtained by the information entropy and subjective method respectively. We rank all the stocks in Shanghai Stocks Exchange according to the two weights respectively. The portfolio with the top 10 stocks of entropy weights was proven to have higher return than that with the top 10 stocks of the subjective weights. And they all have higher return than the Shanghai index which represents the average performance of the Chinese stock market within the 22-month investment period. The empirical study shows the effectiveness of the improved-PROMETHEE method in the decision making process of value investing.

Author Full Names: Ren, Yike; Hao, Xiaoyan; Du, Haifeng
Article Title: Rural-Urban Migrants' Social Integration and Their Health-The Moderating Effects of Social Support Networks-The Moderating Effects of Social Support Networks
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: rural-urban migrants; social integration; social support networks; mental health; physical health
Abstract: Using data of 2010 rural-urban migrants' development survey, this paper analyzes the effects of social integration on rural-urban migrants' mental and physical health and test the moderating effects of social network by OLS regression and Ordinal Logistic regression. These results indicate: scattered rural-urban migrants' have better mental health than concentrated ones; it is harmful to rural-urban migrants' mental health if they were discriminated; and the better mastering cities' dialect, the better physical health. Social support networks moderate the relationship between social integration and mental and physical health: 1) sizes of instrumental support networks weaken the effects of discrimination on rural-urban migrants' mental health; relation configuration of instrumental support networks negatively moderate the effects of mastery of dialect on mental health. 2) sizes of social contact support networks positively moderate the effects of living condition on physical health; configuration of instrumental support networks strengthen the effects of discrimination on physical health; configuration of social contact support networks weaken the effects of mastery of dialect on physical health, while the sizes of instrumental support networks strengthen these effects.

Article Title: Young Nurses at Work and High Quality Care. Ambitions and Values of a New Generation
Source Title: INNOVATION AND SUSTAINABLE COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE: FROM REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT TO WORLD ECONOMIES, VOLS 1-5
Conference Title: 18th International-Business-Information-Management-Association Conference
Author Keywords: Healthcare organizations; quality of care service; nursing; newcomers
Keywords Plus: ORGANIZATIONAL SOCIALIZATION; SOCIAL SUPPORT; SATISFACTION; RETENTION
Abstract: This paper aims at contributing to the research concerning quality care in Healthcare sector through the investigation of motivations, work values and career ambitions of a new generation of nurses. The importance of individuals' wellbeing and job satisfaction among health-care employees is well recognize for increasing quality of the care service. Further, the turbulence of nursing labor market and extremely staff shortage push the healthcare organizations to invest in their human resources in order to create conditions for their development and wellbeing. This paper, highlights and reviews previous empirical studies on young nurses values and attitudes toward this profession and work environment. Further, contributions on human resources as determinants of quality in healthcare service are investigated. In conclusion, some propositions will be presented for further research in this area in order to give support to policy makers and healthcare organizations for managing young nurses generations.

Article Title: INVESTMENT COMPONENT OF ECONOMIC GROWTH UNDER CONDITIONS OF THE REPUBLIC OF KAZAKHSTAN
Source Title: VITH RYSKULOV READINGS: SOCIO-ECONOMIC MODERNIZATION OF KAZAKHSTAN UNDER CONDITIONS OF GLOBAL FINANCIAL INSTABILITY
Conference Title: International Scientific Forum of the 6th Ryskulov's Readings - Socio-Economic Modernization of Kazakhstan Under Conditions of Global Financial Instability
Author Keywords: Kazakhstan; economic growth; investments in fixed assets; modernization and diversification of the economy; the economic and mathematical modeling
Abstract: Purpose - The purpose of this paper is to research and analyze the impact of basic socio-economic indicators on the effectiveness of the investment component of the economy and submit recommendations for improvement to raise capital for economic growth in Kazakhstan. Design/methodology/approach - In the study of dependencies of investment in fixed assets, consumer price index, refinancing rate, employed in the economy, cash in circulation for 12 years (quarterly) and the dynamics of the GDP of the RK based on econometric modeling had revealed a causal relationship between economic phenomena and defined direction of communication, which allowed to identify the factors that have a significant impact on the variation of the process. Originality/value - The value of the work is collecting bank of basic statistics in the context of quarters for the years 2000-2011, which is based on in-depth assessment of the investment of state allows to smooth out a number of levels studied the interaction of economic growth from a number of definite and indefinite factors of RK. Findings - This research shows the functional dependence of the economic growth of Kazakhstan for a significant period in the history of the country on the level of investment in fixed assets and the amount of cash in circulation. The main conclusions of this paper is the need to increase investment inflows in the real economy for sustained development of the national economy.

Article Title: A Study on Tax Policies under the View of Income Equality and Social Welfare
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: SSY welfare index; Kakwani index; tax policy; income equality; social welfare
Abstract: On the basis of combining the SSY welfare index with Kakwani decomposition method, this paper put forward two corollaries about the relationship between tax policies and social welfare. Using these two corollaries, we estimated and ranked the elasticities of China's social welfare to different tax policies. It indicated that it is superior to implement tax deduction policies of indirect taxes than direct taxes. And we proposed two suggestions for tax reform: (1) smooth the levels of tax rates of individual income tax, and lower the overall tax rate appropriately; (2) combing the planning tax reform of integration of value added tax and business tax in China, decrease the overall tax rate of value added tax and busidess tax.

Book Editors: Skarpa, P; Ryant, P; Cerkal, R; Polak, O; Kovarnik, J; Vyskocil, I
Author Full Names: Velecka, M.; Falta, D.; Javorova, J.; Vecera, M.; Andrysek, J.; Studeny, S.; Chladek, G.
Article Title: THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE TEMPERATURE IN THE STABLE, COMPOSITION AND TECHNOLOGICAL PROPERTIES OF MILK IN CZECH FLECKVIEH BREED
Conference Title: MendelNet International Ph.D. Students Conference
Author Keywords: cows; stable temperature; milkcomponents; technological properties; Czech Fleckvieh
Abstract: The aim of this research was to evaluate the relationship between the temperature in the stable, composition and technological properties of bulk tank milk samples. Altogether 87 bulk milk samples obtained in identical herds within 87 weeks (3. 6. 2010 - 2. 2. 2012) were divided into six groups depending on average diurnal pattern of air temperatures (less than 0.00 degrees C; 0.01 to 5.00 degrees C; 5.01 to 10.00 degrees C; 10.01 to 15.00 degrees C, 15.01 to 20.00 degrees C and above 27.00 degrees C). Viewed samples came from the farm GenAgro Ricany a.s., which reared with Czech Fleckvieh breed. The average values of milk parameters under study (n = 87) were as follows: rennet coagulation time 199.53 sec., curd quality class 1.50, titratable acidity 7.03 degrees SH, active acidity pH 6.72, milk density 1.030 kg. l(-1), fat content 3.95 g. 100 g(-1), protein content 3.58 g. 100 g(-1), lactose content 4.80 g. 100 g(-1), solids non-fat content 8.99 g. 100 g(-1) and the average diurnal temperature was 11.05 degrees C. We found that with increasing average daily temperature in the barn with a statistically significantly (P<0.01) reduced the quality of the curd and the protein content, fat content, solids non-fat content, while increasing the lactose content. Rennet coagulation time, titratable acidity and active acidity remained almost unchanged (P>0.01).

Article Title: FORECASTING MONTHLY UNEMPLOYMENT BY ECONOMETRIC SMOOTHING TECHNIQUES
Source Title: ECONOMIC COMPUTATION AND ECONOMIC CYBERNETICS STUDIES AND RESEARCH
Author Keywords: unemployment; labour force survey; estimation; forecasting
Abstract: In the last year, the need for high-quality statistics for labour policy became increasingly significant Requirements of European official statistics for short-term indicators on labour market statistics created the opportunity to develop a national methodology for deriving monthly unemployment estimates directly from the Labour Force Survey (LFS) results. LFS is carried out by Romanian National Institute of Statistics on quarterly basis, according to the European regulations and methodology. The unemployment is measured in line with International Labour Organization criteria, ensuring full comparability at European level. In response to this requirement Romanian National Institute of Statistics has developed such a methodology that generates the forecast of monthly unemployment rate using data from the series of Labour Force Surveys. The journey for reaching the present model was a complex and difficult one. The main part of the study is aiming to present comprehensively the work performed for developing the actual method used for regularly producing the monthly unemployment estimates. The outputs of the method are presented in the second part of the paper showing the usefulness brought by the model. It also emphasizes the seasonality of the time series suggesting an improvement of the Holt method. Main unmet expectations of the methodology are closing the present paper.

Article Title: Study on Public Power Sector's Reaction to Media in Public Emergencies in China
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: public emergency; public power; public obligations; media; Spokesman; leader; problems and solutions
Abstract: Nowadays public emergency in our society continue to occur. To deal with emergency public event is the legal authority and obligations of public power sector. Spokesman and leaders of public power sector are the major roles who react to the media. But there are many failures of public power sector reaction to media in the specific practice due to the reactor's illegal systems, inaccurate purpose, incorrect attitude, feeling out of control, oversight situation, inappropriate expression, loss of knowledge and loss to practice skills. These are possible choices through learning the knowledge and skills of law and policy, public sector management, media, communication. Using the time strategy, personnel strategy, content strategy, the purpose of strategy, response strategies and the tactic strategies will certainly enhance the effectiveness of reaction to the media, to defuse the crisis, to create a good public image and enhance the credibility of the power sector as well as to achieve ultimate social harmony.

Article Title: The spirits of Corporate Social Responsibility: senior executive perceptions of the role of the firm in society in Germany, Hong Kong, Japan, South Korea and the USA
Author Keywords: corporate social responsibility; culture; corporate governance
Keywords Plus: UPPER ECHELONS; CULTURE; INSTITUTIONS; DIMENSIONS; AGREEMENT; PARADOX; CSR
Abstract: We report our findings on cross-societal variations in values concerning Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) held by senior executives from five economies. We find that executives in all five economies are concerned with the roles of their firms in society, with those in Japan most so and those in Hong Kong least so. However, executives in each context have different conceptualizations of how firms contribute to society. The data suggest variation along three dimensions: implicit versus explicit CSR, stakeholder-oriented versus production-oriented CSR within implicit CSR and different main stakeholders within stakeholder-oriented CSR. We discuss the implications of these findings for future research on CSR and for comparative business systems.

Article Title: Choice-Based Pricing for Parallel Flights with Multiple Predetermined Prices
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: Revenue Management; Parallel Flights; Non-homogeneous Poisson Demand; Threshold Policies
Abstract: We propose an analytical model to assist the decision-making process for parallel flights in a monopoly line. Passengers traveling on the same origin-destination pair can choose between two flights run by the same airline. The two flights are scheduled at different time periods of the day. Demand follows a non-homogeneous Poisson process at each price level. Both flights have multiple passenger classes who are price sensitive. Passengers make their purchase decisions based on fares and seat availability. To optimize expected revenues, the airline integrates seat inventory control on the two flights. We formulate the problem as a continuous-time stochastic control model. Through analyzing the properties of the expected value function, we derive its close-form solution. Specifically, we show that an optimal policy is featured by a sequence of threshold points at which price changes are made. This threshold control policy is simple and easy to implement.

Article Title: The Development Relationship Study between Six Cities around Chongqing in Sichuan and Chongqing Port
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: Chongqing port; correlative analysis; gray correlation model
Abstract: ` This article writes under the background of Six Cities Integrate to Chongqing in Economy policy, through analysis on the present development situation of six cities around Chongqing in Sichuan province and Chongqing port, using correlative analysis methods and gray correlation model to study the relationship between the GDP of six cities around Chongqing and the throughput of Chongqing port. The results show that the total amount of GDP in six cities around Chongqing is well related to the throughput in Chongqing port. In 12 correlation degrees, the largest is between container throughput in Chongqing port and the GDP of Dazhou, while that comes second between cargo throughput in Chongqing port and the GDP of Guang'an. Among these six cities, it is not existed that one is weakly related to container throughput and at the same time, is also weakly related to cargo throughput of Chongqing port. The research results of this paper will provide theoretical basis for concerned departments to make decisions.

Article Title: Assessing forest governance from a 'Triple G' perspective: Government, governance, governrnentality
Author Keywords: Forests; Government; Governance; Governmentality
Abstract: This paper aims to assess the emergence of the concept of forest governance in the field of forest policy analysis. This assessment is mainly theoretical in nature. The various meanings and main criticisms of forest governance will be dealt with. In so doing, the paper applies the so-called 'Triple G' perspective (government, governance, governmentality). Firstly, the paper explains the emergence of the forest governance concept from the shortcomings of forest government, or 'state forestry' (overexploitation, policy failure, corruption). In a next step, it also criticises the concept of forest governance, now using a governmentality perspective. This latter view assumes that control by the state and self-governance by people go hand in hand. It thus challenges one of the key assumptions in many governance studies, namely that the state has substantially withdrawn from the forest sector and that forest politics has been relocated from the state to the market and to society. Authors: Li, ZW; Shi, YD; Chen, W; Kargbo, M
Author Full Names: Li, Zhuwei; Shi, Yongdong; Chen, Wei; Kargbo, Mohamed
Article Title: Do Attention-Grabbing Stocks Attract All Investors? Evidence from China
Author Keywords: abnormal volume; account information; attention-grabbing stocks; extreme returns; heterogeneous trading behavior
Keywords Plus: INDIVIDUAL INVESTORS; PERFORMANCE; BEHAVIOR; RETURNS; TRADERS; DIVERGENCE; PATTERNS; VOLUME; NEWS
Abstract: Using a unique and comprehensive data set of China's Shenzhen Stock Exchange, we test whether all investors adopt attention-grabbing stocks. Only the less-wealthy individuals, the Small Group, are found to have the tendency to pursue attention-grabbing stocks, such as abnormal-volume stocks, extreme-return stocks, and initial public offering stocks. By contrast, wealthy individuals, such as the Middle and Large Groups, are the sellers of attention-grabbing stocks and prefer non-attention-grabbing stocks, thereby exhibiting a behavior resembling that of institutional investors. The wealth levels of individual investors may account for such heterogeneous trading behavior. Heterogeneous trading behavior may address one reason why only the less-wealthy individuals do poorly in China's stock market. Accordingly, we suggest that the Small Group manage the stock selection problem through consultancy with investment institutions.

Article Title: Father Knows Best: Using Adam Smith to Teach Transactions Costs
Author Keywords: ethics; Adam Smith; transactions costs; impartial spectator
Abstract: Adam Smith's moral philosophy can be used to introduce economics students to the important idea of transactions costs. The author provides a brief background in this article to Smith's moral philosophy and connects it to the costs of transacting in a way that fits easily into the standard principles of microeconomics classroom. By doing so, instructors can also demonstrate to students that there are connections between ethical behavior and market outcomes.

Article Title: Making it real: The benefits of workplace learning in upper-secondary vocational education and training courses
Author Keywords: Educational economics; Vocational education and training; Workplace learning
Keywords Plus: SELF-EFFICACY BELIEFS; PROPENSITY SCORE; APPRENTICESHIP; PSYCHOLOGY; ATTAINMENT; ECONOMICS; RETURNS; SKILLS
Abstract: In OECD countries, 'real world' upper-secondary vocational education and training (VET) programs are used to engage less academically oriented youth in learning, while helping to prepare them for post-school work and/or further education. In general terms, VET programs with high employer involvement, such as apprenticeship schemes, are considered to be superior to classroom-based VET programs that are typically found in many English-speaking countries. In this study, we examine outcomes from a potential 'third way': classroom-based VET with a short-term structured workplace learning component. Using propensity score matching and PISA data linked to information from the Longitudinal Survey of Australian Youth, we find this model is associated with higher school completion rates and better employment transitions. Article Title: Estimating the relationship between calculated financial need and actual aid received using quarter of birth instruments
Author Keywords: Student financial aid; Educational finance
Keywords Plus: HIGHER-EDUCATION; NET PRICES; COLLEGE; AFFORDABILITY; POLICIES
Abstract: When calculating financial need, the FAFSA does not consider the parental income of students who turn 24 years old. This paper uses the student's quarter of birth interacted with the treated cohort to instrument for financial need. Using the interaction mitigates many of the concerns regarding quarter of birth instruments. A dollar increase in financial need is associated with 15 cents in federal grants and 47 cents in loans. However, the relationship between financial need and institutional aid is, on average, small and statistically insignificant. The exception is that institutions with large endowments do allocate more aid to more-needy students. (C) 2014 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Article Title: Effect of audits on the extent of compliance with wastewater discharge limits
Source Title: JOURNAL OF ENVIRONMENTAL ECONOMICS AND MANAGEMENT
Author Keywords: Audits; Wastewater discharges; Environmental management; Clean Water Act
Keywords Plus: ENVIRONMENTAL PERFORMANCE; SELF-REGULATION; ENFORCEMENT; INCENTIVES; MANAGEMENT; REGULATIONS; INSPECTIONS; ISO-14001; RESPONSES; PROGRAMS
Abstract: This study explores the effect of environmental self-audits (audits), which represent an important type of environmental management system practice, on the extent of facilities' compliance with wastewater discharge limits. Theoretically, audits may (1) improve compliance by enhancing the effectiveness of treatment technologies and pollution prevention methods, (2) undermine compliance by distracting facilities' personnel with audit-related administrative burdens, or (3) not influence compliance because these effects neutralize each other. By examining the extent of compliance, our study's results reflect both improvement toward and beyond compliance. By assessing compliance with multiple pollutants separately, our study examines whether audits influence the control of different pollutants uniformly. Lastly, we employ a dynamic panel estimator, which allows us to explore whether facilities adjust their discharges dynamically, while controlling for any inertia in facilities' pollution control systems. Our study empirically examines the U.S. chemical manufacturing sector between 1999 and 2001 using survey and publicly available EPA data. (C) 2014 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

Article Title: Women and the European crisis
Author Keywords: Austerity; European economic crisis; gender; social justice
Abstract: The article raises questions about how the economic crisis is being played out 'in place', taking an embodied, generational and gender perspective. 'Place' is used in a political context by examining how global realities are experienced in place, and the author argues the need to look at the everyday realities of the crisis from a gendered ontological perspective in order to counter grand narratives of gloom and doom where women (whether old, young, migrant, heterosexual or otherwise) are particular victims. By discussing local contexts of the gendered realities of the crisis in three southern Europe areas, the author shows the possibility of changing the crisis narrative from one of overwhelming paralysis to one of potential transformation. The focus is on the rise of resistance, solidarity economies and new types of communities in the search by women in southern Europe for alternatives to neoliberal capitalism.

Article Title: A New Cluster-Based Financial Vulnerability Indicator and Its Application to Household Stress Testing in Croatia
Author Keywords: cluster analysis; Croatia; household financial vulnerability; stress testing
Abstract: In this paper, we propose a new approach to household financial vulnerability analysis employing cluster technique in the identification of potentially vulnerable households. The cluster-based vulnerability indicator is applied to stress testing with the specific aim of assessing the extent to which the prolonged economic downturn following the Great Recession of 2008-9 hurt indebted households in Croatia. We compare the results based on the new approach with those based on traditional methods. Interest rate shocks have a stronger effect on household vulnerability in the traditional approach, whereas decrease in employment is found to be more disruptive in the cluster-based approach.

Article Title: Visions and scenarios of democratic governance in Asia 2030
Author Keywords: Futures studies; Causal layered analysis; Scenario; Visions; Democracy; Governance and Asia
Abstract: Using the Six Pillars foresight workshop process, forty-five Asian political, policy and activist leaders explored the futures of democratic governance. Organized and funded by Oxfam and the Rockefeller Foundation, the organizing hypothesis was that without a change in the nature of governance in Asia, poverty could not truly be uprooted. Changes in governance needed to be imagined and created from the ground up, not just imposed by the past or the elite. Five visions with accompanying causal layered analysis were developed by participants. Generally, these visions focused on more inclusion not just at the level of voting, but in terms of the participatory creation of alternative futures of culture, technology, economy and polity. Article Title: Publishing Research in the JEE
Author Keywords: economic education; publishing; research; A20
Keywords Plus: ECONOMICS; STUDENT; PERFORMANCE; GENDER; INCENTIVES; ATTENDANCE; HOMEWORK
Abstract: Based on several years of editing papers for the Research Section of the Journal of Economic Education, four suggestions are made for increasing the likelihood that a submitted manuscript is accepted for publication. The primary theme is that the hypotheses investigated should be based on economic theory developed in the manuscript, and researchers should carefully plan the research design and data collection before conducting the quasi-experiments common in the economic education literature. Specific examples are given for each suggestion.

Authors: Kim, BJ; Yun, YS; Cin, BC; Kim, Y
Author Full Names: Kim, Byoung Joon; Yun, Young Sup; Cin, Beom Cheol; Kim, YoungJun
Article Title: Home Bias in Emerging Bond and Stock Markets
Author Keywords: dynamic panel data regression models; flight to quality; home bias; informational asymmetries; return chasing
Keywords Plus: PANEL-DATA; INFORMATION COSTS; ERROR-COMPONENTS; EQUITY MARKETS; HIGH TURNOVER; RISK; MODELS; DIVERSIFICATION; SPECIFICATION; FLOWS
Abstract: In this paper, we empirically examine sizes and sources of home bias in both bond and equity markets for twenty emerging countries and twenty-two developed countries over the 2001-11 sample period. The average size of home bias in both bond and stock markets is found to be much larger in emerging countries than in developed countries. Using the explanatory variables in two categories of economic development and market performance, we employ dynamic panel data regression models to analyze major sources of home bias. The main results are the following: First, market performance factors generally affect home bias more strongly than do economic development factors. Second, market factors including market return, volatility, and liquidity support various hypotheses under informational asymmetries, such as return chasing, risk aversion, and flight to quality. Third, among macroeconomic factors, it is shown that real gross domestic product growth has negative effects and country leverage has positive effects on a specific home bias, backing up the size-bias and the flight-to-quality hypotheses, respectively. Finally, and perhaps most important in this paper, the effect of bond market performance on equity home bias is found to be significantly stronger than the effect of equity market performance on bond home bias from the market interaction model estimation, suggesting that a policy design needs to begin with increasing bond market efficiency to reduce equity market home bias.

Article Title: Determinants of the Variability of Corporate Effective Tax Rates: Evidence from Romanian Listed Companies
Author Keywords: effective tax rates; firm-specific determinants; tax planning
Abstract: In this paper, I investigate the determinants of firm-specific corporate tax rates for nonfinancial companies listed on the Bucharest Stock Exchange over a twelve-year period (2000-2011). Using a fixed effects panel data estimation model to account for individual firm heterogeneity, I find that capital intensity, leverage, and loss carry-forward provisions negatively affect corporate effective tax rates; company size and labor intensity have no effect; and profitability has a positive effect. Going beyond the deterministic investigation, the paper cannot provide evidence of tax-planning activities for the companies considered. Moreover, legal differences between financial and tax accounting related to provisions are found to have a positive effect on firm-specific effective tax rates.

Article Title: Innovation and the dynamics of global warming
Source Title: JOURNAL OF ENVIRONMENTAL ECONOMICS AND MANAGEMENT
Author Keywords: Climate change; Global warming; Clean energy; Innovation; Exhaustible resources
Abstract: Global warming and the carbon cycle are a dynamic system with positive feedbacks. Fossil fuels are exhaustible resources. These two facts mean that innovation in clean energy technology, rather than mitigating global warming, can lead to a permanently higher temperature path. This paper explores the impact of innovation in the simplest model linking the economic theory of exhaustible resources with positive feedback dynamics in the carbon cycle. (C) 2014 Elsevier Inc. Authors: Blázquez Cuesta, M; Moral Carcedo, J
Author Full Names: Blazquez Cuesta, Maite; Moral Carcedo, Julian
Article Title: Women's part-time jobs: Flexirisky employment in five European countries
Author Keywords: part time employment; labour flexibility; women workers; part time worker; family responsibilities; EU countries
Abstract: European countries currently have segmented labour markets with flexible but insecure -flexirisky - jobs, resulting in significant inequality between different categories of workers. Part-time jobs are one example: their flexibility may help workers reconcile work and family life, and increase women's labour force participation, but part-time employment can also result in new forms of inequality, thereby undermining EU equal opportunity policies. Empirically analysing labour market transitions in Denmark, France, Italy, the Netherlands and Spain, this article shows part-timers - who are mostly women - to be at higher risk of unemployment. It calls for strengthening equality between part-time and full-time workers in terms of employment stability.

Article Title: Global foresight: Lessons from a scenario and roadmapping exercise on manufacturing systems
Conference Title: 4th Conference on Future-Oriented Technology Analysis (FTA) - Practice in Search of Theory
Conference Location: European Commiss Joint Res Ctr, Inst Prospect Technol Studies, Seville, SPAIN
Conference Host: European Commiss Joint Res Ctr, Inst Prospect Technol Studies
Author Keywords: Innovation; International foresight; Roadmapping; Scenarios; Vision-building
Abstract: Geographical dispersion, organisational and cultural differences, and the diversity arising from a large number of participants are all characteristics of international foresight exercises. In this paper, the authors develop four principles for the design and management of global foresight exercises building on the experience of designing and managing the Intelligent Manufacturing Systems (IMS) 2020 project. The first principle is understanding interconnected innovation systems. This principle ensures that participants position the foresight exercise and their own activities in a global context. The second principle is responsiveness towards diverse languages and cultures. This principle strengthens commitment and encourages learning and creative problem solving. The third principle is capacity to reconfigure international networks. This principle is about taking advantage of existing organisational structures and facilitates timely and efficient mobilisation of stakeholder communities. The fourth and last principle is 'glocal' impact orientation. This principle ensures that foresight activities are connected to both local and international decision-making structures. Overall, due to the heterogeneity of global projects, all four principles must also be implemented in keeping with a scalable design approach. (C) 2014 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: De Witte, K; Geys, B; Solondz, C
Author Full Names: De Witte, Kristof; Geys, Benny; Solondz, Catharina
Article Title: Public expenditures, educational outcomes and grade inflation: Theory and evidence from a policy intervention in the Netherlands
Author Keywords: Public expenditures; Grade inflation; Educational attainment; Standardized central exam
Keywords Plus: STUDENT-ACHIEVEMENT; SCHOOL RESOURCES; STANDARDS; ACCOUNTABILITY; QUALITY; CONSEQUENCES; PERFORMANCE; EARNINGS; IMPACT; LEVEL
Abstract: This article argues that resource expansion can fail to improve actual student performance because it might cause educators to soften grading standards (i.e., induce grade inflation). Our theoretical model shows that, depending on schools' and students' reactions to resource changes, the overall effect of resources on education outcomes is ambiguous. Schools, however, have an incentive to adjust their grading structure following resource shifts, such that grade inflation is likely to accompany resource-driven policies. Exploiting a quasi-experimental policy intervention in the Netherlands, we find that additional resources may indeed induce grade inflation, particularly when the resource increase is limited. Authors: Zhang, XT; Zhang, P; Yang, XY
Author Full Names: Zhang Xiaotong; Zhang Ping; Yang Xiaoyan
Article Title: The EU's New FTA Adventures and Their Implications for China
Abstract: With the EU having an adventure in PTA negotiations after the serious setback from the Doha Round trade negotiations, China becomes increasingly concerned about the potential trade diversion effects and the possible G2 domination by the EU and the US in terms of rule-making power in world trade. This article offers both a quantitative and qualitative analysis of the potential impact on China from the EU's two major PTA negotiations one with the US and the other with japan. Chinese intellectuals who are paying attention to these two FTAs, however, have very mixed opinions, which can be characterized as positive, negative or what can be termed as 'marginal impact'. On the basis of the analysis of the mixed opinions, the authors make further predictions about the possible responses of the Chinese government towards new PTA strategy of the EU, and suggest that the EU's FTAs need to exhibit sign of greater amicability and accepting of differing opinions and most importantly, they should form building blocks, instead of stumbling blocks,for the multilateral trading system.
